comment_data.body: If we change this to have `trace` enabled by default, we might as well remove the option and just be verbose always.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -18,4 +18,4 @@ jobs:
       - uses: rhysd/action-setup-vim@v1
         with:
           neovim: true
-      - run: nvim --clean -es +"lua require('scripts.lintcommit').main({trace=false})"
+      - run: nvim --clean -l scripts/lintcommit.lua main -trace

comment_data.body: It's not enabled; `-trace` disables, `+trace` enables. We can use a different syntax if you prefer?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -18,4 +18,4 @@ jobs:
       - uses: rhysd/action-setup-vim@v1
         with:
           neovim: true
-      - run: nvim --clean -es +"lua require('scripts.lintcommit').main({trace=false})"
+      - run: nvim --clean -l scripts/lintcommit.lua main -trace

comment_data.body: `--trace` and  `--no-trace` is more standard in (shell) scripts?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -18,4 +18,4 @@ jobs:
       - uses: rhysd/action-setup-vim@v1

comment_data.body: But no strong opinions either way, I just didn't understand the syntax.
